Legal_Issue: Whether the Trade-marks Opposition Board erred in allowing Orange's trademark registration due to potential confusion with Telus' mark
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from decision of the Trade-marks Opposition Board
Evidence_Assessment: Board reviewed evidence including memorability, market context, and resemblance of marks
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed; Orange's trademark registration upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On Telus to demonstrate likelihood of confusion
Legal_Rule: Confusion between trademarks is assessed based on first impression and imperfect recollection
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to Board's decision
Procedural_Issue: Admissibility of new evidence on appeal
Grounds_for_Claim: Likelihood of consumer confusion between 'Future's Bright' and 'Future is Friendly'
Outcome_on_Merits: No reasonable likelihood of confusion found
Review_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of confusion based on statutory factors
Key_Evidence_Considered: Distinctiveness of marks, use in market, resemblance, consumer recollection
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law under the Trade-marks Act
Legal_Rule_Source: Statutory interpretation of the Trade-marks Act
Defendant_Response: Orange defended registration, asserting lack of confusion
Decision_Authority: Trade-marks Opposition Board, affirmed on appeal
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of registration due to alleged infringement
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative opposition proceeding followed by judicial appeal
Outcome_of_Review: No error found in Board's assessment
Governing_Rule: Assessment of confusion in trademark law based on first impression and imperfect recollection
